markdownRemark.html:
Last month, I had the privilege of flying to Seattle and attending TSConf, a one-day single-track conference all about TypeScript! I want to share some of my key takeaways and what I’m excited about going forward.

Developer Experience

The TypeScript team is engaged with the community and invested in improving the developer experience. During the keynote, Anders Hejlsberg, one of the core developers on the TypeScript team at Microsoft, showed an example where a type error in a deeply nested object would surface a deeply nested pyramid of errors. The TypeScript team responded to feedback from the community and flattened the pyramid of errors to be more readable.

Another example is the improvements the TypeScript team made to the TypeScript Playground (http://www.typescriptlang.org/play/), which makes it even easier to get started with trying TypeScript. Recent updates have added a formatter that supports JSX syntax, the ability o save code and settings to the URL to return later, and support for different versions of TypeScript, which in turn enables the ability to try out experimental features that are part of beta versions. Speaking of…

Experimental Features

TypeScript has the ability try out experimental features that are being proposed for JavaScript. Two key examples (and two features that I’m personally very excited about) are optional chaining and null coalescing. At time of writing, they’re both in stage 4 of the TC39 process (TODO links to proposals) but they are currently in the beta version of TypeScript 3.7 and it’s very likely that they’ll be released on TypeScript first!

Community Momentum

TypeScript has been gaining significant traction over the past few years. Based on the State of JavaScript survey from 2018 (https://2018.stateofjs.com/javascript-flavors/typescript/), the percentage of responders that have used TypeScript and would use it again has been steadily rising. Similarly, in the Github Octoverse analysis also from 2018 (https://octoverse.github.com/projects#languages), TypeScript made its way into the top 10 for the first time in 2017 and jumped up to seventh place in 2018. Additionally, in the same Github analysis, DefinitelyTyped, the open-source repository of type definitions, is one of the top open source projects and had 6,000 unique contributors in 2018. I also recall one of the speakers at TSConf mention that DefinitelyTyped has more PRs created that can be feasibly reviewed by the maintainers (unfortunately I didn’t manage to take a note of this at the time, so don’t quote me on this). There’s a lot of energy and momentum around TypeScript right now and I’m excited for what’s in store!

Start with the Problem

My last takeaway is from Lauren Tan, an engineer manager at Netflix. The main theme of her talk was the importance of starting with a problem and then finding the right technology to solve that problem. Sometimes, as engineers, we’ll learn about a shiny and cutting edge new technology and try to find a way to introduce it to our team, yet run into issues convincing other folks to hop onboard because it doesn’t add business value or solves a manufactured problem.

At the core of TypeScript lies a solution to a problem.

Going forward

It was easy for me to get started with exploring TypeScript — I just had to open the playground and it was all there for me to try, including the new features that I’ve wanted in JavaScript for a while. I’m about to start a new project at work and I’m excited about building all of the React components with TypeScript because it’ll provide type safety, help catch bugs, and improve code readability and developer productivity.

Lastly, I’m looking forward to wearing these awesome TypeScript socks that were included in the goodie bag at the conference. My current company Gusto has a shoeless office — a perfect chance to show them off!

frontmatter.title: Top Takeways from TSConf
frontmatter.description: Key takeaways, what I’m excited about going forward, and a comfy pair of socks.
